content:
Alexander Kriegisch said
Thanks for your response. I have, however, no idea what exactly you are talking about. Have you seen the screenshots I sent, showing what kinds of file handlers I have configured?

Yes I saw them, considered them and moved on.

What more than reset them to "always ask" like this can I do?

Delete them like I told you to.

I do appreciate terse replies as long as they contain all necessary information, but yours was a bit too terse.

You apparently had found how to change the action, as evidenced by your posting a picture of the relevant dialog. I had assumed you had looked at the list and were aware delete was one of the options.

What is clear in these images you posted is that the images are correctly identified and a media type PNG and JPG respectively.

I have extracted the relevant information from the two images below. The first and most obvious thing I see after the fact that the files appear to have been correctly encoded with media type it that the application being offered to load the files is not the same.

One is fotoanzeigethe other is fotoanzeige (Standard) I have no idea hat the distinction means to Windows but that is where this is going.

I really doubt that deleting the setting will fix what is most likely a problem in windows file associations to media types Vs file extension from file manager. But it is incumbent to eliminate Thunderbird entirely from the equation first and deletion removes all references to handlers from the settings so a true fresh slate can be achieved.

content:
Applied this fix, from ...

DavidGG 

   Top 10 Contributor

1/27/25, 6:11 PM

Thunderbird thinking Inbox is a drafts folder… So funny… xD

So I figured there had to be a way to fix this without having to install the add-on, and there is. I installed the add-on to set the flag instead of to remove it, then did successfully remove the flag without using the add-on doing this: 

   Open the account Copies & Folders settings.    Under Drafts and Templates, choose Other, then select the account Inbox. You have to select the folder that has the problem here, not some other folder.    Close the account settings (not sure this is necessary).    Open Copies & Folders again and change the Drafts folder setting back to what it was. This is where having selected the right folder before matters, because it's when the folder that had been chosen to store drafts stops having that role that the flag is removed.

HTH… And looking forward to see more funny stories like this… :) 


  Now, when I doubleclick an email in the inbox, it does not go to draft message, but does go right to reply to sender.  If I rightclick the message, i can open in new tab just fine.  Is there a setting for doublecliick menu within TB?   Thanks

content: Look for a prior proflle in c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird\profiles. the name would be abook.sqlite and history.sqlite (for collected addresses). You can get them back with tools>import>importfromafile>addressbook and then tick the sqlite option and then locate and select the file

content:
AT&T accounts require that you create a secure mail key and use that in TB in place of the account password:

https://www.att.com/support/article/dsl-high-speed/KM1010523/

As for gmail, check that OAuth2 is the authentication method for the incoming and outgoing servers, and that cookies are accepted in TB (not browser) Settings/Privacy & Security.
creator: sfhowes

content:
Select the desired address book to be exported. Do not select 'All Address Books'. Click the 3 dots right next to the address book in the left pane - Export. Select 'LDIF' as file type.

Import the exported LDIF on the other computer. Press Alt or F10 in the main Thunderbird window to bring up the menu bar in case it is hidden. Select 'Events And Task' from the main menu bar or press Alt-N - Import.

Repeat the steps above if there are multiple address books to be transferred.
creator: christ1

content:
With the IMAP account set up, just do this:

  1. - click the advanced button in 'synchronization&storage' for the account to verify that desired folders can be downloaded
  2. - then, click file>offline>download to ensure that all messages are downloaded. browse a few here and there to verify that you have the contents, not just the headers
  3. - then, if you're confortable with windows file explorer, do this:
    • - click help>troubleshootinginformation
    • - scroll down to 'profile folder' and click 'open folder'
    • - exit thunderbird
    • - click the imapmail folder and then the account folder
    • - copy the folders, such as inbox, sent' to Mail\Local Folders (but IGNORE all files ending in .msf)
    • - restart thunderbird and check that you have all the messages saved
    • - you may now delete the account if not further needed
  4. if not comfortable with that, let me know

content:
birdlover said

can't get printscreen to work here, dunno why. I do screenshots on a regular basis...not working for me here.

You might find that the issue is the type of keyboard, especially if it is a laptop. Microsoft suggest Fn + Windows logo key + Space Bar to take a screenshot, is the print screen button does not work. https://support.microsoft.com/en-au/windows/keyboard-shortcut-for-print-screen-601210c0-b3a9-7b58-bc40-bae4dcf5f108

The following link is to an article on screenshots put together by the Firefox folk. It does provider relevant information once you get past the first Firefox specific instruction 

How do I create a screenshot of my problem?

While David is a fan of manual copying for email folder contents. I prefer to use a more point and click method offered by the import export tools addon. https://addons.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/addon/importexporttools-ng/?src=ss

My preference is largely because IMAP mail is transitory in that is is synchronized. By exporting the mail from Thunderbird (exactly where David is going) the syncronised link to an account is broken. My preference for the addon is that as a part of it's export it checks that the latest copy of each mail in in the local store that is being exported. Thunderbird does not always have a full copy of an IMAP email stored locally or depending on account settings it may only be cached locally, so occasionally you can get a missing message body by relying on the original download only. The drawback is the export process using the addon is significantly slower.

THe addon offers the opportunity to export mail in a number of formats, EML and MBOX being perhaps the most useful. Windows likes EML and you can work with individual emails from the file manager. Thunderbird native storage format is MBOX so the files are very easy to import back into Thunderbird after the non-account linked archive has been created.

I will but out again now.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
La modalità risoluzione dei problemi fa due cose sostanziali: - disattiva le estensioni - disattiva l'accelerazione hardware

-> https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/modalita-risoluzione-problemi-thunderbird

Per cui è altamente probabile che la causa si una di queste due. Prova anzitutto a disattivare tutte le estensioni che usi e a riattivarne una sola per volta fino a trovare quella responsabile del rallentamento.

Se questo non funziona, disattiva l'accelerazione hardware -> https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/impostazioni-thunderbird-pannello-avanzate#w_impostazioni-avanzate
